RULES TO PASS ON AND ABOUT THE PIONEER HISTORY QUESTIONNAIRE

Since early settlers lived in very different times of history, from one place to another, and because of different circumstances, the questions have been divided into three parts.

PART I: The story of the family and its history.

- To include any and all information about this family.

PART II: The permanent home.

- To include the date the house was built after living for a time in quarters elsewhere; the date of the permanent home built; when arrived at the homestead; the date of the first permanent home.

PART III: General.

- Including anything applying to either Part I or Part II of the questionnaire.

Send completed questionnaires to:

University of Idaho Office of Extension, Box 4512, Moscow, Idaho 83844.

Please send your completed questionnaires to:

In 1904 I traded my homestead the N.W.¼ of Sec. 20 Tp. 8 Rge 8 into a half section of Sec. ½ of Sec. 25 Tp. 9 Rge 7 west 2. You will see houses erected on both parcels placed on the homestead. I had a sod farm 16x30 on the bought land a frame farm 16x28 until 1914 when I built a cement block barn 28x48 with hip roof. Blocks were made on farm.
In 1904 I traded my homestead the N.W. ¼ of Sec. 20 Tp. 8 Rge 8 into a half section of Sec. ½ A Sec. 25 Tp. 9 Rge 7 west 2 from will see houses erected on both parcels planned on the homestead. I had a sod farm 16x30 on the bought land and a frame farm 16x28 until 1914 when I built a cement block farm 28x48 with hip roof. Blocks were made on farm.
In 1917 I built a large house 28 x 28 ft. 
lumber and stucco outside. It had a full size 
basement of cement and was heated by a 
furnace. It had kitchen, parlor, living room, 
wash room and pantry on 1st floor and 6 
bedrooms and a bathroom upstairs. It was 
plastered and was built by Mr. Harold Gibson 
and myself. It had a well in cellar with force 
pump by hand in wash room.
In 1917 I built a large house 28x28 ft. 
It was outside it had a full size 
kitchen, dining room and was heated by a 
fireplace. It had a living room, parlor, dining 
room and pantry on the floor and 5 
bedrooms and a bathroom upstairs. It was little 
plastered and was built by own Harold Gibson 
and myself. It had a well in cellar with force 
pump by hand in wash room.
PART I: THE "TEMPORARY" SHACK, SOD OR LOG HOUSE.

1. What year was this house built? 1902 on homestead

2. During what years did you live in it? 1902 to 1905

   How long did you think you might live in it when you built it? 100 feet

3. What was the location? (township, range, and post office). SW 8 Rg 8

4. Is it still in existence? No

5. What material was it made of? Log

   How long did it take to build it?

6. How large was it, and how many rooms did it contain? It was 10 x 12 ft.

   How were they arranged?

7. Who built it? My father, brothers and uncle built

   What was it as I was working out

8. How were the walls finished inside? (e.g., rough boards, mud plaster, painted etc.) Never finished only plaster + logs

9. What kind of floors did you have? Sand

   What covering did you have on the floor (rushes, linoleum etc.)

10. What expenses did you have connected with the building of the house? Little only window made door rubber and door catch & hinges

11. Describe any special problems or unusual happenings connected with its building. It was built in the winter & 1901 so took longer than in summer

12. How many people lived in the house when it was first built? Just myself, later?

13. What means of heating did you have? Small cook stove

14. What means of lighting did you use? Coal Oil lamp bought in Arcola spring of 1902 and I have it yet can show you if you want it

15. Was there a cellar? No

   Where was the door to the cellar? (in kitchen floor, other place?)

PART II: THE PERMANENT HOME.

Note: For some persons, this section may include a description of more than one house. If so, you may include answers for each, showing changes and differences from one house to another. If you wish, you may describe your first permanent house on this form, and tell about others on a separate sheet (or other questionnaire forms will be sent to you upon request). If you have lived in several houses, and especially if they have been of the same type of houses, you may wish to answer questions only about the first one or two (or perhaps an outstanding house in which you lived), and merely mention the others in question 16.

In all cases, be sure to make it plain which house you are writing about, using dates (and perhaps places) to identify each.

16. Give the location (township, range, and post office), of the house, (or houses) described in this part of the questionnaire, and the years you lived in it (or them). If you lived in other houses besides those you intend to describe in this questionnaire, give their location, and the years you lived in each.

Top Rd. 7 and 2 built in 1905 one room frame
Shortly 12 x 16 lived in till 1917 when I built
A larger house described on separate sheet
